Introduction

Tetanus is an acute, life-threatening neuromuscular disease caused by the neurotoxin tetanospasmin, which is produced by Clostridium tetani.

Pathophysiology



Clostridium tetani is a spore-forming, gram-positive anaerobic bacteria normally found in soil.  The disease develops when spores enter the body through a break in the skin.  The spores germinate in anaerobic conditions (like that of a puncture wound) and subsequently produce a potent metalloprotease exotoxin (tetanospasmin or tetanus toxin).  Using retrograde axonal transport (

figure 1
), the toxin migrates through lower motor neurons to inhibitory interneurons in the CNS at the level of the spinal cord and brainstem; there, it acts on the anterior horn cells, blocking the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine, GABA).  This action leads to uncontrolled firing of alpha motor neurons and subsequent tonic muscle contraction.

Epidemiology and risk factors



Tetanus is rare in resource-rich regions due to widespread vaccination with tetanus toxoid.  However, cases can occur among individuals who were incompletely vaccinated as children and those who have not received appropriate booster vaccines.  Tetanus rates are higher in resource-limited settings.



Risk factors for developing tetanus include:



  • Puncture wounds (eg, from nails and splinters)
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Burns
  • Umbilical stump infections (eg, in neonates born in nonsterile conditions)
  • Surgery involving bowel flora or performed in nonsterile conditions
  • Diabetes mellitus with infected ulcers on the extremities

Clinical presentation

Generalized tetanus



The most common form of tetanus is generalized tetanus.  Patients usually have a history of a puncture wound that leads to inoculation with C tetani spores approximately 7-10 days prior to symptom onset.  In some patients, the wound may go unnoticed.



The most common initial clinical manifestations of tetanus are usually painful intermittent muscle spasms including:



  • Jaw stiffness due to masseter muscle spasm (trismus/lockjaw); frequently the first manifestation of tetanus
  • Facial muscles spasm, producing a bizarre "smiling" appearance (risus sardonicus)
  • Spasm of the back and neck muscles causing extension and arching of the back (opisthotonos); occurs in about half of patients


Muscle spasms are frequently triggered by sensory stimuli (eg, loud noises, light, touch).  Patients are at risk for life-threatening stridor and respiratory failure due to diaphragm and upper airway muscles spasms.  Autonomic overactivity usually occurs a few days into the illness and can cause sweating, labile blood pressure, and tachycardia.  Patients usually have a normal level of consciousness.

Local and cephalic tetanus



Localized tetanus is rare, with symptoms of muscle contraction isolated near the wound side; cephalic tetanus is also rare, with symptoms of cranial nerve involvement due to a head wound.  These forms often progress to a more generalized tetanus.

Neonatal tetanus



Neonatal tetanus presents within the first few weeks of life, typically within 5-7 days after birth.  It usually occurs as a result of infected umbilical stumps in infants born in nonsterile conditions to mothers who are not immunized.  Immediately after birth, these infants have a normal suck and cry; however, infected neonates then become irritable and have difficulty feeding due to tonic spasm of the masticatory muscles (trismus).  The spasms and hypertonicity eventually become more generalized and opisthotonus develops, often within hours of the first symptoms (

figure 2
).  The disease progresses in neonates more rapidly than in adults, perhaps due to the shorter length of neurons.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of tetanus is clinical and should be suspected in a patient who has characteristic symptoms of muscle spasms and rigidity, particularly if the patient is unlikely to be adequately vaccinated or has a history of recent cutaneous trauma.  Laboratory confirmation with blood culture is generally not necessary and often impractical as the bacterium is difficult to culture and the clinical syndrome stems from toxin elaboration, not bacterial invasion.  Wound culture can provide supportive evidence but often takes several days for results, so it is not usually performed.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of tetanus includes:



  • Botulism:  is caused by C botulinum, which also produces a toxin that causes neurological dysfunction.  However, botulinum toxin causes impairment of presynaptic acetylcholine release, which leads to bilateral cranial nerve deficits with a symmetric descending flaccid paralysis rather than rigidity and muscle spasms.
  • Meningitis:  is a CNS infection due to microbial invasion that can cause confusion and stiff neck, but it is unlikely to cause painful muscle spasms.
  • Rabies:  Rabies virus is transmitted via the saliva of an infected animal during a bite wound and spreads by retrograde axonal transport through peripheral nerves and enters the CNS.  Patients with rabies can develop painful pharyngeal spasms but they usually also have hydrophobia, fever, and hyperactivity.  Trismus is not usually seen.
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS):  can present with severe muscular rigidity; however, patients usually have fever and altered mental status in the setting of use of dopamine antagonists (or withdrawal of dopamine agonists).

Management

Tetanus prophylaxis

  • For patients who have received â‰¥3 tetanus toxoid doses, a booster dose of tetanus toxoid is indicated only if their last tetanus dose was â‰¥10 years ago for clean or minor wounds or â‰¥5 years ago for dirty (eg, dirt, feces, saliva) or severe (eg, punctures, avulsions, crush injuries, burns, frostbite) wounds.
  • Patients who have received <3 tetanus toxoid doses (ie, incompletely immunized) or whose vaccine status is uncertain should receive a tetanus toxoid booster.  If such patients have dirty or severe wounds, they should also receive tetanus immunoglobulin.  Tetanus immunoglobulin primes the immune system but does not confer long-term immunity (only immediate, temporary immunity).


Patients with a clean or minor wound who have had >3 tetanus vaccinations and a booster within the past 10 years do not require an additional vaccine booster.

Active tetanus infection



For those who become ill from tetanus, intensive care is often required for a few weeks.  Patients with respiratory or laryngeal muscle spasms often require intubation and mechanical ventilation.  Limited sensory stimulation is recommended to prevent spasms from occurring (eg, dark, quiet room).  Muscle relaxants, such as benzodiazepines and neuromuscular blocking agents, can be used to treat muscle spasms.



If present, an infected wound should be debrided and antibiotics should be started.  Metronidazole or penicillin G are the preferred antibiotics, usually for 7-10 days.  Human tetanus immunoglobulin can bind residual circulating toxin to prevent further neurological progression and should be administered; however, it cannot reverse the effects of already-bound toxin.

Prognosis



The prognosis of tetanus improves with prompt and aggressive treatment but remains guarded, especially in older adults and neonates.  Resolution of the clinical syndrome usually takes several weeks.  Patients who do recover may have persistent stiffness in the muscles, requiring weeks to months of rehabilitation.  Neonates can have long-term motor deficits and cognitive issues.  Mortality rates vary widely depending on the availability of medical resources and the speed of intervention.  Mortality approaches 100% without treatment, usually due to respiratory failure.

Prevention



Tetanus can be prevented with early vaccination programs.  Current recommendations in the United States are for children to receive a primary three-dose vaccine series around ages 2, 4, and 6 months, with additional doses recommended at 15-18 months and at 4-6 years.  Adults should receive a single dose of tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap), followed by revaccination (booster) for tetanus and diphtheria (Td) every 10 years thereafter.



Prevention of neonatal tetanus is achieved primarily by vaccination of the mother during pregnancy with an inactivated tetanus toxin (tetanus toxoid) as part of the tetanus-diptheria (Td) or tetanus-reduced diphteria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine.  An appropriately vaccinated woman provides transplacental IgG to the fetus, which decreases the incidence of neonatal tetanus by approximately 95%.

Summary



Tetanus is an acute, life-threatening neuromuscular disease caused by the neurotoxin tetanospasmin, which is produced by Clostridium tetani (
